Hopkins is not the only major university beset with budget difficulties—Cornell
and Princeton are others—yet the severity
of the problems promises that the University must redistribute its resources to maintain its division's competitiveness and often
cut funding for necessary improvements.
Top administrators, however, believe
Hopkins could not have foreseen the
budget shortfalls it now faces, shortfalls
that necessitated development of the Five
Year Plan, released in draft form last
month. Rather, they believe Hopkins's
financial ills stem not from overexpansion
or poor decisions, but from revenue shortages resulting from bad timing and unexpectedly small donations to certain University divisions.
Not enough revenue

Eugene Sunshine, senior vice president for

desire to maintain its competitiveness with
other research universities.
"If you want to be competitive for the
kinds of faculty and students we want to
maintain and recruit," he explained,
"there's a significant cost element
associated with that, and that manifests
itself in terms of capital facilities, salaries,
and student aid. The University financial
condition might be a lot different if we
didn't have such high standards."
Like other universities, Hopkins cannot
dip into its permanent endowment to fund
projects. Hopkins may spend only the endowment's earnings and its "quasiendowment," funds given to the University for program support that are treated
as endowment for the purposes of investment but are available for spending.

Provost John Lombardi explained, "Insofar as the University's financial adjustment can be tracked, it tracks to a combination of two or three important
phenomena. The first is the need to
renovate our physical plant in all parts of
the University.
"When we look to find the money to
support the building, we look for three or
four different sources: research funding,
donations from major capital campaigns,
and some amount of support from the state
government," he continued. "What happened to Hopkins has been a lag in the timing of the commitment to build the
buildings and the production of those
revenue sources."

A Johns Hopkins University
professor is working on an artificial blood substitute that may
one day make mass donations
unnecessary.
Biology professor Gary
Ackers is an expert on
hemoglobin, the oxygencarrying protein in red blood
cells. Ackers is part of a team
of scientists trying to create a
blood substitute derived from
hemoglobin.
"Blood banks and hospitals
around the world are greatly
concerned about the problem of
blood supply and shortages,"
Ackers said. "We think we can
come up with a solution, a
.substitute that would not be
identical to blood but could
serve as a temporary life support."

Science
in
Brief
With funding from both the
National Institutes of Health
and the Army, Ackers is studying the structure and function of
mutant hemoglobin—proteins
that vary genetically from the
hemoglobin in normal blood.
By comparing mutant
hemoglobin with normal
hemoglobin, Ackers hopes to
understand better how the
structure of the protein governs
its behavior. The goal, eventually, is to manipulate the
structure to create "designer
proteins" that substitute• for
blood with no ill side effects.

the field.
When you think about it, it

round bye, and have three play
six and four play five. The winner of three vs. six would play

biased sports writers and coaches

Sugar, and Orange Bowls. Each

getting the national championship
game. The excitement of a sudden death playoff will draw larger
crowds, more media, and more
income than the present system.

Citrus, Gator, Holiday, etc.),
they can still exist by inviting the
teams which don't make the
playoffs. Let's face it, the teams

The release of the University Five Year
Plan last month answers a year's worth of
conjecture and worry. Triggered by the
now infamous deficit in the School of Arts,
and Sciences, the plan was developed by
a team of high-ranking administators in collaboration with principal members of the
Hopkins community. The plan, claiming to
represent the "collective understanding"
of the participants, sets specific limits and
goals for University resources and will
serve, barring rejection by the Board of.
Trustees, as the "general blueprint" for
resource allocation.
The plan's proposal for financial reform
depends on identification of and commitment to crucial divisions and programs
within those divisions: non-crucial programs and divisions wkll be phased out. The
temporary creation of a reserve fund, to
which divisions will contribute, will serve •
as a stop-gap measure to correct the immediate deficit. In this way, Johns Hopkins'
hallowed decentralized tradition will be
preserved.
Arts and Sciences, as one of "the original
stars in the Hopkins galaxy," will remain,
the plan promises, a "viable, research intensive, tightly focused and internationally competitive" division. Yet, in order to
remain in the decentralized Hopkins galaxy,
Arts and Sciences must toe the galactic
budgetary line, and bring its deficit finances
under control in the next five years by
reducing faculty size, increasing undergraduate enrollment, and postponing construction and renovation.
It is the inherent contradiction between
objective and adjustment that troubles us:
Arts and Sciences cannot cut back its most
vital components and still hope to maintain
its high standards.
The policy of faculty reduction through
attrition is one we find especially frightening. It has strained departments and has
caused subsequent decline in diversity of
course offerings, even in this past semester.

A Johns Hopkins University
professor is working on an artificial blood substitute that may
one day make mass donations
unnecessary.
Biology professor Gary
Ackers is an expert on
hemoglobin, the oxygencarrying protein in red blood
cells. Ackers is part of a team
of scientists trying to create a
blood substitute derived from
hemoglobin.
"Blood banks and hospitals
around the world are greatly
concerned about the problem of
blood supply and shortages,"
Ackers said. "We think we can
come up with a solution, a
.substitute that would not be
identical to blood but could
serve as a temporary life support."

Science
in
Brief
With funding from both the
National Institutes of Health
and the Army, Ackers is studying the structure and function of
mutant hemoglobin—proteins
that vary genetically from the
hemoglobin in normal blood.
By comparing mutant
hemoglobin with normal
hemoglobin, Ackers hopes to
understand better how the
structure of the protein governs
its behavior. The goal, eventually, is to manipulate the
structure to create "designer
proteins" that substitute• for
blood with no ill side effects.

Women's hoops tops .500 mark
by Rachel McGuckian
The Johns Hopkins women's
basketball team recorded a much
needed win last night over
Lebanon Valley College to put
themselves on the better half of
the .500 mark. The 64-26 victory
put the Blue Jays back on the winning track after a tough loss to nationally ranked Franklin & Marshall on Saturday.
Last night's victory over the
Flying Dutchwomen leaves
Hopkins at 7-6 on the season. The
win was a turning point in
Hopkins's play after, according to
Coach Nancy Blank, "a shaky
start in the new year." The Lady
Jays, with strong efforts by
sophomore Beth Donnelly (sixteen points) and freshman Kern
McTiernan (twelve points), completely overwhelmed their opponents, outscoring them 30-14
in the first half. According to
Donnelly, "We finally pulled
together and played like we knew
we could."
Coming out of the locker room
with a comfortable lead, the Lady
Jays suffered a breakdown in concentration. Hopkins went
scoreless for eight minutes, until
Donnelly hit two free throws and
the Lady Jays set up full-court
pressure. According to Coach
Blank, "we worked hard to take
them out of their offense."
The Blue Jays did just that,

converting Lebanon Valley errors
into Hopkins baskets. Freshman
Julie Slye continued her good
play, scoring 10 points and pulling down 7 rebounds for the Lady
Jays. McTiernan dished out 3
assists and recorded 3 steals,
while Williams (six points) added six steals and two assists.
Sophomore co-captains Kristi
Kantowski and Julianne Rolapp
contributed six and ten points
respectively.
Coach Blank was pleased with
her team's performance. "We
needed to see our regulars do
well, especially since we have
been struggling since we've been
back from break."
Last Saturday, the Lady Jays
fell 62-50 in a hard-fought bout
with tenth-ranked Franklin &
Marshall. Julie Slye had her best
day as a Blue Jay, scoring fifteen
points and pulling down fifteen
rebounds. Tracy Jo Williams add;
ed twelve points in the losing effort, which was much closer than
the final score indicates. According to Coach Blank,' It (the
game) went all the way to the
final four minutes. It was a four
point game all the way through
until the end. The twelve point
finish wasn't indicative of the
play."

manage to put an end to F & M's
Anne Krumvine's attempt to
break the NCAA Division III

crowds, more media, and more
